To live on mars you would have to be hidden from Gamma and other forms of ionizing radiation. That means life in a bunker underground. Any time you go outside it is like stepping into the remains of an old nuclear war or living in a uranium mine area...outside the actual orebody.

The skies are "hot" in a radiometric sense. The "hot" charged particles would age you and probably would eventually make inhabitants sick many different ways.

So....here are a few Q/A's from NASA work...see references below. The Problems are lifted from the NASA work and clarified a bit.

Problem 2 - By what factor is the average Dose in space during the cruise to Mars

greater than the ground-level Dose rate on the surface of Mars?
Answer: About 415/215 = 1.9 times higher in space...(almost 2x).

That means living on the surface of mars is a bit safer...roughly two times safer than space. .

Problem 5 - If an astronaut remained on Earth, the normal background radiation dose
rate is 3 milliSieverts/year. How many equivalent years of normal Earth exposure
would a single trip to Mars produce?

Answer: you get 0.88 Sieverts cumulative space dose and staying-on-mars dose over the 960 day trip = 338 milliSieverts/year. So it equals 338/3 = 112 years!

In that same time...if you stayed on earth the whole 960 days of trip time you would have gotten...of course, 2-3 years of earth dose instead of 112 years of radiation exposure from a normal space/mars round trip dose rate.

But what about just living on Mars like a homesteader? Using the NASA numbers....

Walking around on mars gives you 0.7 mSv/day and over the course of 365 days (an earth year) we get : 365days/year x 0.7mSv/day = 255 mSv per year (on Mars). On earth we expect to get 3 mSv per year. (millisieverts)

255/3 = 85 Living on Mars is 85x earth dosage using the NASA numbers

These are very general estimates...but

If I walked around earth with say a gamma ray meter (a scintillometer) and found an area that was 85x normal...I would know I was in a "hot" area. I would start hunting around in cracks and crevices for hot spots to test for uraniferous material. 10x is nothing but 100x is worth looking at if you were hunting for radioactive material here on earth. Really hot uraniferous ore grade material is 10,000x and pegs the meter.

It would not necessarily be dangerous at least crudely if your 85x came just from gamma ray type sources but it would be kind of "hot". There would be radiation that is worse than gamma, it is cosmic energy coming from star bursts etc. so the radiation exposure on mars is worse than 85x. You would want to live underground.

There is water on Mars. But it is all frozen. Hence there is nothing to "bind" dust. The dust on Mars is SUPER fine. It would get into EVERYTHING. Also: the surface contains a chemicals called perchlorate and hydrogen peroxide - not in very high concentrations. But they effectively make UV light 10 times as deadly. Anything you would plant (even it didn't die from frost) would be killed by the ground. Eating it would poison yourself. No water. Poisons soils.  Very low atmosphere and no oxygen . Deadly cold. No energy source and deadly doses of cosmic radiation. But hey - let's do it anyways.

Please ask your friend about this: Why do parachutes deploy at Mars in a near vacuum (6 millibar, at the surface), but they won't deploy in simple experiments here on Earth? Consider the Mars Rover traveling toward Mars in the vacuum of space. At what point would it see 6 millibar, at the surface or aloft? Parachute tests for the rover were conducted in ... wait for it ... wind tunnels on Earth. Tests were also conducted at high altitude above Earth where the atmosphere is still much thicker than above, and at the surface of, Mars. So, where's the truth? What magic permits these parachutes to operate in near vacuum and slow an inbound spacecraft? Is Mars' atmosphere truly at 6 millibar? Give fluctuations in the atmosphere at Mars, is it enough to enable a parachute to slow a spacecraft?

Another problem we'll probably solve at first with hydroponics is all of the soil on Mars is poisoned with perchlorates.  If we do use it as is to grow food, any plants that do manage to grow will be poison.  So we'll have to separate the perchlorates from the soil. so what I'm gathering more and more is that, in order to Terraform Mars, we need to give it a moon (same for Venus).
A larger moon than it has; enough to disrupt the core and get it churning again, enough to ease Mars's wobble, and maybe also thereby help "grow" an ozone layer. A more active core means more vulcanism, means more gases into the atmosphere. Genetic engineered plants, or artificial photosynthesis factories, could pull carbon out of the atmosphere and increase the oxygen content. Mars would have to be richer in oxygen than Earth since it doesn't have the nitrogen we have, but too much would be poisonous to us, too.
Perhaps a series of controlled impacts from icy moons of Jupiter or from Saturn's rings (or icy asteroids if we could find them) could both thicken the atmosphere and add inert gases such as nitrogen to its atmosphere. Could also be good practice for when we scale Vesta or maybe Io into Mars orbit (sorry, Titan, with its petrochemicals, is bound for Venus...)
Push come to shove, robot freighters could scoop-dive the upper atmosphere of Jupiter/Saturn and drag it back to Mars (probably frozen into a solid by the time it gets there, anyway). Detachable, replaceable cargo containers that could just be dumped from low orbit, maybe.

One thing I haven't seen much discussion of is the Moon's role in plate tectonics and the Earth's magnetic field. The tidal stresses induced in the Earth's interior by the moon may play a significant role in keeping the outer core liquid, creating the magnetic field. wich is essential for life. This movement of the liquid core also plays a role in plate tectonics. Platectonics plays a role in sequestering carbon and replenishing atmospheric nitrogen, and thus is also essential for life.

The only other terrestrial planet with a magnetic field is Mercury, whose field is much weaker than Earth's. In Mercury's case, the tidal stresses caused by its proximity to the Sun would account for the continued liquefaction of the core.

If this is the case, then a requirement for life on extrasolar planets would be that they must be under some form of tidal stress, either from having a large moon or from being Earth-sized moons of a close-orbit gas giant. However, close-orbit gas giants are invariably migrating inward and will become hot Jupiters, whose moons would then be to hot to sustain life. Thus such moons would not be long-enough lasting to harbour complex life.

This leads me to think that while planets are common, the circumstances that gave rise to the Earth-Moon system are correspondingly rare, meaning that life - particularly complex life - is also most likely very rare.

Ok. These are fine criticisms for someone who for whatever reason felt like we might be able to openly walk around and breathe the open air on Mars' surface. That is obviously not the case for those many enthusiasts today excited about colonizing Mars. We know very well that we'll need habitats and pressure suites. However, once you accept that, Mars looks pretty good.

There are also many great opportunities for a great life in a Martian colony. Once you accept you need habitats that are air-tight, well insulated, and shielded from radiation, there emerges an opportunity for a growing paradise. That is a space where you can walk around in your socks and pajamas all day with no worries of mosquitoes or harsh weather to deal with. Inside the habitat, you will do lots of gardening and cooking, and building tools, furniture, clothes, etc. You will have greenhouses with indoor waterfalls and pools in which to swim. You probably grow plants using regolith after heating the water ice out of it and washing it 3 to 5 times to removes the salts and then fertilizing. But you will also use aquaponics with a near perfectly closed loop of fish adding nutrients to water for the plants. Algae will clean your water and also, together with the plants, produce large amounts of oxygen to breathe. You will use carbon filters to clean the air and fans to circulate it. You will probably use hydrogen gas for heating and cooking (as it also destroys any CO buildup). Outside, you'll have a smelter and foundry for the extremely abundant ore-grade rocks all around (especially iron and nickel). You will then have a small wire mill for making electrical wires or cables, rollers for making sheet metal. You will send DC current through red hot metals to form permanent magnets used for electricity generation. You may build any number of vehicles for exploration and regolith collection outside. You'd probably use compressed CO2 for energy storage for vehicles and outside tools, as well as water batteries, inside the habitat. In addition to fish, you'd likely have chickens, crickets, and honey bees. You'd have personal quarters but also large greenhouses built with tempered glass bricks and/or PVC membranes. PVC can be mass-produced from chlorine + CO2 in a high-pressure steamed enclosure.

One way is to build corrugated steel walls and re-enforced lifted floors and roofs, similar to how shipping containers are made... except add overhanging roofs will regolith over the top to shield the habitat and to allow windows on the sides to look out, without being exposed to the radiation. One could also melt out a palace in one of Mars' glaciers, using insulative membranes for grow rooms. Or, find the flow exits to lava tubs and build inside there. You could use inflatable walls to seal off two ends, spray hot plastic on the rock walls to ensure an air-tight seal, and build whatever you want in there.... Mirrors can be used to direct larger amounts of sunlight in through special corridors or through fiber optics cabling.

4:30 "It doesn't have a moon like we do to stabilize its orbit. It can wobble because there's no moon to keep it just straight up." Mars has two moons but they're much smaller and less massive than earth's moon.

1) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moons_of_Mars
"Compared to the Earth's Moon, the moons Phobos and Deimos are small. Phobos has a diameter of 22.2 km (13.8 mi) and a mass of 1.08×1016 kg, while Deimos measures 12.6 km (7.8 mi) across, with a mass of 2.0×1015 kg. Phobos orbits closer to Mars, with a semi-major axis of 9,377 km (5,827 mi) and an orbital period of 7.66 hours; the semi-major axis of Deimos's orbit is 23,460 km (14,580 mi), with an orbital period of 30.35 hours."

2) https://www.space.com/18135-how-big-is-the-moon.html
"Earth's moon is the brightest object in our night sky. It appears quite large, but that is only because it is the closest celestial body. The moon is a bit more than one-fourth (27 percent) the size of Earth, a much larger ratio (1:4) than any other planets and their moons. Earth's moon is the fifth largest moon in the solar system.

The moon's mean radius is 1,079.6 miles (1,737.5 kilometers). Double those figures to get its diameter: 2,159.2 miles (3,475 km), less than a third the width of Earth. The moon's equatorial circumference is 6,783.5 miles (10,917 km).

The moon's mass is 7.35 x 1022 kg, about 1.2 percent of Earth's mass. Put another way, Earth weighs 81 times more than the moon. The moon's density is 3.34 grams per cubic centimeter (3.34 g/cm3). That is about 60 percent of Earth's density. The moon is the second densest moon in the solar system; Jupiter's moon Io is denser, with 3.53 g/cm3."

Im surprised you didnt mention the biggest hurdle of life in mars, for us humans. The lack of gravity. Mars has like a third of the mass of the earth, so the gravity is way weaker. Over time this will cause dystrophia in the muscles and bones of any human colony trying to live for extended periods of time in Mars.

Another major problem with colonizing Mars is the more extreme eccentricity of its orbit. All orbits are elliptical - but Earth's orbit is relatively circular, varying in 'distance from the sun" by a meager 3 million miles (90-93 million miles). That difference in Mars orbit is about 100 million miles (150-250 million miles) So, not only does Mars get about 40% of the solar energy the Earth collects (as she mentions) - that percentage can vary wildly depending on orbital position - dropping, at times, to percentages in the 30's

Good video. I'm not anti-space or science. I just think any attempt to go to Mars with current technology is that those pushing the idea are skiing way over their skis! I grew up in the ‘50’s and watched our early attempts until the Moon was reached. Some really interesting things were learned with the Shuttle and the ISS. However, it’s one thing to orbit the Earth, it’s quite another to live on the Moon or Mars. I've also thought that if people are going to go anyway, we had better send tons of materials, food, etc that will be waiting for them. If not we will only be sending people to their graves!

The biggest obstacle or one of the biggest to overcome, is getting there and back. People being literally stuck in a can racing to the unknown, even under the best of conditions, is going to be a mentally challenging situation. They better really like being together! Then there’s the constant need to work out, which is going to put a huge strain on resources. The gravity, or near lack thereof, is going to be another huge problem as the crew is going to have to learn how to walk again and even more so IF they survive to return to earth. Let’s face it,  we were created to live on earth. Next, living in isolation, as the crew would be doing, is going to be extremely difficult. It was one thing to know that should something go wrong, the Apollo crews knew they were only 4 days from home. Anyone going to Mars is going to have to deal with loneliness never before endured by humans! If anything goes wrong, there will be no rescue. If help is sent, they will likely find nothing but corpses. Frankly, I doubt it would be worth it to send anyone, because they may find themselves in the same situation. Going to Mars is one of the dumbest ideas in the history of bad ideas! Going to the Moon and building on the Moon is better for several reasons but the best is that it is at least close to home. Learn the survival skills on the Moon first. Build the technology, let it mature. Then, when we’re ready and can get there in a matter of weeks, then maybe  going to Mars might make some sense.

One upside of hostile environment, no life and everybody being in spacesuits/ sealed habitats is that you can use nuclear power

I can imagine one possibility: Tunnel underground, and build an enormous vacuum sealed cavern. Then suspend habitation units from the walls, anchored by non conductive materials. This would block most of the radiation.

From the surface, pipes can bring electricity from solar and nuclear power cells. Sterling engines might actually harness nuclear the best, due to Mars low temperature. When the surface temperature is too high for the sterling engines to work, above 50 degrees Fahrenheit, the crew can go up to the surface for maintenance and exploration, and use battery heat pumps to keep their habitation pods warm, pumping fluid antifreeze from the heat Pumps on the habitation pods to surface radiators for direct heat exchange.

Right now SHEDDING radiation seems to be the best place for researching habitability on Mars. The surface radiation and radiation from nuclear power cells will need to shed most of itself to be acceptable for human living.

There are a number of plant, bacterial, algal, fungal and proozoic species that consume radiation. We need to study cultivation methods for these, and see which ones could survive in artificial habitats on Mars. If Mars truly does turn out to be sterile, perhaps we can seed its caves microbes that will start to slowly build back up a thicker atmosphere. That would take a few hundred thousand years, but something our descendants might benefit from

Extracting water from the atmosphere can be accomplished by compressing into a separator (tank, maybe even with a centrifuge), which the water can then form and drop down and be collected -> The compressed atmosphere then can be discharged into a turbine to extract some of the energy spent pressurizing in the first place. Carbon Dioxide, O2 and Carbon extracted by plants. Energy can also come from space with satellites using solar cells and either laser or microwave down or both (microwave would be less affected by atmosphere changes). Water, O2, energy. A shelter is a shelter but also Mars have a network of caves where settlements could more rapidly exploit using blowup shelters while more permanent ones are built over time. Water, O2, energy, shelter -> what is left is food and all the bacteria types needed for humans to sustain life for themselves. Atmosphere thickness is highly variable all the time on Mars. Summer and late afternoon at low altitude might give you 3-4 torr while winter and just before dawn at the same place might get you 7-8 torr. That double in a dark winter night. On earth we still get about the same pressure rise but it’s not noticeable with our relative high normal pressures.

Also this 1% atmosphere is annoying never say about as that’s just wrong and over estimates the Mars atmosphere. So use the word less than and 1%. Or just use the real shocking numbers. Standard earth atmosphere Vs the best pressure Mars can pump out gives Mars only 0.9% earth standard atmosphere and Mars on its worst day gives you 0.4% standard earth atmosphere. And that’s at the lowest spots on Mars too.

So Mars is between 0.9% and 0.4% earth standard atmosphere of 760 torr.

Missing MANY other reasons why Mars is inhospitable. The lack of gravity would lead to anatomy changes which would include limbs and heart; humans were evolved to work in Earth gravity so who knows what long term effects will occurs on Mars? What we do know is that fetal development in zero gravity most likely won't work. It appears gravity is needed for proper organ placement and tissue development. So while Mars' .38G MAY be enough for fetal development... we won't know until we try (hopefully with animals first). Next up we have bacteria and viruses to worry about. Humans are walking ecosystems containing tens of thousands of different bacteria and viruses. We live in balance with these organisms because they've evolved with us. But creating a reproduction of this ecosystem may be hard to achieve; also mutation rates would likely be increased by radiation exposure. What we do know is that keeping the ISS clean and healthy has proven quite problematic because the ecosystem is so hard to balance. Mars lacks not only a magnetosphere but also a ozone layer; this combined with the thin atmosphere contributes to making radiation a major issue. Coupled to that, the sun periodically flares; potentially wreaking havoc on a Martian colony. A word about radiation. The processors on the various martian probes are antiquated by comparison to those in household use today. The reason, again, is radiation. Think 1980's technology! So when you arrive on Mars you will be taking a massive technology backstep.

"We haven't found any evidence for any type of life on Mars."
We have found very strong evidence for life on Mars and, in fact, one of the key members of the team that developed the experiment for NASA says the data proves that there is life on Mars. He says the data shows that gases released from Marsian soil samples start to increase before sunrise can change the environmental conditions, in anticipation. Something that cannot be explained by chemicals alone as it requires a circadian clock.
In any case, the Viking experiment certainly gave a positive result for life.
In addition to that, there are releases of methane and oxygen of unknown origin. That is not proof of life but it certainly is evidence.

Comparatively speaking the Earth is SIGNIFICANTLY more hostile to life than Mars is. Without even considering the "hostile" aspect towards any species other than humans, the Earth has many thousands of ways for one of us to get ourselves killed. Severe weather, extreme temperatures both hot and cold, various other environmental hazards, and most abundant of all; other life. All told humans are pathetically easy to kill, either directly (by claws, teeth, etc...) or indirectly, such as the transmission of viruses or diseases. Rabies, for instance, can infect basically ANY mammal species on the planet, and not only can they then pass it on to a human, the actual symptoms of the disease itself MAKE the infected much more likely to attack. Once symptoms appear, regardless of the species, rabies is 100% fatal. As in, if you aren't vaccinated and happen to get rabies, by the time you know you're already guaranteed to die.

Sadly I found this rather shallow because there was no connection made between the planetary magnetic fields, the Van Allen belts, atmosphere and radiation.
The main issue with Mars is lack of a consistent magnetic field . There are some areas with the odd magnetic loop, but not others, so there are pockets of thin atmosphere.
Note: Mars has no reason to wobble when Jupiter comes near unless its mass is distributed unevenly, the varying axis tilt could perhaps be due to the strong magnetic field of Jupiter picking up on stray magnetic loops on Mars and pulling it around.
But back to the magnetic field. The only reason any planet has an atmosphere is because its magnetic field prevents it from being blown away. Mars's 95% CO2 is not an accident, the lighter gases simply get blown away by the solar wind, but the heavier ones stay. Similar thing on Venus.
On the earth the magnetic field protects the atmosphere by diverting solar charged particles into bands or belts around the earth, known as the Van Allen belts. These lethal areas of radiation are therefore full of solar radiation that now doen't strike the surface, unlike on Mars and the moon, killing all life.
So lets have less 'I don't knows' and more physics please !

The "fossil fuels" question is moot. Even if there are hydrocarbons available on Mars (which is not at all dependent on life - see the lakes of hydrocarbons on the surface of Titan and quantities of methane present in various atmospheres in the solar system), the problem is that the available atmosphere is not suitable for combustion of such fuels. With the low availability of atmospheric oxygen, it would be folly to use imported or chemically generated oxygen to combust hydrocarbons, when that oxygen is desperately needed for other purposes (like creating an artificial earth atmosphere for Martian residents and visitors). It would also require enormous energy to release oxygen from Mars's oxygen-rich minerals.
The only source of energy that would reliably produce energy for Mars exploration would be nuclear. That would mean the importing of nuclear fuels that have a sufficient density of available energy to make their importation worthwhile. That also assumes that uranium, thorium or other fissable materials are not readily available on the surface of Mars.

The tilt of Mars happens on earth as well. And as things goes this has pretty recently been discovered when scientists discovered the shifting and flipping of earths magnetic poles. The tilt shift happens to all rotating bodies in space. For example, Russian Cosmonauts discovered the rotational flipping effect when a screw drifted away from the panel they were unbolting. they noticed durring its rotation (which one would readily assume would remain constant on one rotational axis) all of a sudden Flipped the opposite direction while still rotating, then seconds later flipped back again, repeating over time.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1VPfZ_XzisU&ab_channel=Veritasium It is unknown if planets completely flip on their rotational axis,but they do know currently the earth is tilted off its normal recorded axis.

I fear the idea of "Hoping Mars warms up and gets a thick atmosphere." Or alternatively artificially trying to start that process. With no magnetic structure to defend Mars, the process that blew its atmosphere off can happen again however it happened previously. I surmise that Mars has no Radioactive core materials. Especially with no water around there wouldn't be anything to stagnate Radioactive decay through phases. Here on Earth in France there are caves that go through periods like this. They warm up, melt snow and ice and then stagnate due to the water filling the caves. At least, as I recall. It was in a Science video I had watched years ago. But, the point here is that Mars would need to have liquid water to impede the decay rate. Otherwise it would run its course, cook off and then finally end. This may have been what fueled Mars early volcanic life. But with no tektonic system there isn't any continuous friction and pressure change. If the core of the planet goes solid. That is the point that the planet will begin a continual temperature loss. It will either need to take in more heat than it loses or it will degrade permanently. This is literally like taking a large pot of soup at boiling temperature and going outside in the middle of winter and expecting it to keep itself hot overnight. It isn't possible. The vastness of space is cold and unforgiving if you are not prepared.

Mars probably also has less fissile material. Despite being interesting, this video unfortunately has some important omissions. I would like to address them.
1) A lack of magnetic field is responsible not only for thin Martian atmosphere but also for similar percentage of carbon dioxide as Venusian one. Solar wind has tendency to slowly blow atmospheric gases away. Gases with monoatomic molecules such as oxygen are most likely to be blown away.
2) Ionizing radiation is a concern but without estimated biological doses, it is meaningless to discuss it. A six-month long trip to Mars, 500 days on Red Planet and 6 months on their way back will expose astronauts to 500-1000 milliSieverts. An acute (delivered over up to 72 hours) dose of 1 surgery usually results in short-term change of blood composition, nausea, sometimes vomit but is vary rarely lethal itself. Recently there have been studies on mice exposed to similar dose rate for six months. The mice experienced memory loss anxiety and social disorders.

Ms. Nuno details a lot of problems with the idea of us living on Mars. She focuses on the Mars-centered issues, but I bet there are some human-centered issues that are also barriers.
I suggest that the human body is tuned to Earth in a way we can only discover by space exploration. She mentions the gravity of the Earth compared to Mars, the Earth's magnetic field, and the Moon in the context of what differences they mean to each planet. But those elements also have an effect on the human being on Earth, a factor which would be quite different - and possibly life-threatening - on Mars.
Today, for example, astronauts have vision issues after long space flights, caused by changes in the fluid in the eyes, those changes the result of low/no gravity. So that fluid actually is 'tuned' by Earth. Regardless of the environmental constructs tp protect space travelers, we may not be able to recreate all the factors needed to replicate Earth. The limbic system, the chemical composition of the blood, circadian rhythms and even emotions might be affected in ways we can't predict.
I'd bet that there are other systems normal in Earthlings which don't function or go haywire after extended periods on another planet.

CMEs are less of a problem on Mars if you can build your bases under ground (11 feet of concrete is what I've been told). The problem is we don't have spacecraft that can block CMEs and prevent them from baking our astronauts.

It was a worry during the moon shots, but those lasted a couple of weeks, and we'd schedule them when the Sun was during its calmer spells. Given that the short trip to Mars is nine months, we can't just hope the Sun will behave. On the other hand, whatever spacecraft material we use to block solar flares in space may also be usable on Mars to build shelter insulation.

To truly Terraform Mars, we would have do some pretty horrific things to it.  Planetary bombardment  by asteroids from the asteroid belt is what I remember someone suggesting.  This would accomplish several things. It would introduce new metals to the planet, it would increase the mass=gravity to help prevent the loss of gases, trigger a global upheaval and disruption of the surface of the planet's surface.  Volcanic activity might ensue which could lead to greenhouse gas event. The disruption of the surface would allow the new material to sink to the planet's core. With a new increase in mass, then pressure might be sufficient to remolt the cold core and allow a reformation of a magnetic field.  This would take hundreds of years before the surface would settle down enough to allow exploration again.   The downside is we don't know what this would do to the Earth's rotation or what effects it would have on the Earth itself. Too many unanswered questions to risk all life here just on the off chance of bringing back a dead world.

2:38 While the tilt is chaotic it is in no way random. True randomality might only occur at the quantum level. Anything at a larger scale than that is perhaps seemingly random is only chaotic. Chaos is just a situation where the pattern, sequence, cycle or whatnot plays out with so many factors and/or over such a period of time that it's outside of our ability to predict future states and outcomes. Retroactively we can see that order comes out of chaos. The double pendulum experiment for instance. Most just use it to illustrate chaos. I don't get why there's this assumption that other planets are unsuitable for life.

1. Life on earth developed and evolved through earth's unique and changing climate over eons. In other words life on earth is designed for earth. It's akin to asking if humans can live at the bottom of the Mariana trench.

2. That said, life unique to other planets can exist. It may be strikingly different to life as we know it or not as varied as life on earth. May just be microbes or just simply unrecognizable to us.

3. Despite our perception of other planets being inhabitable, the are many examples of life forms on earth that not just survive but thrive in regions on earth once considered impossible for life. E.g near active volcanoes or sulphuric vents at the bottom of the sea.
So to assert a planet cannot support life because we deem the climate extreme is illogical.

What about Venus. I know you can't just go down to it's 450 degree oven of a surface to mine materials, but you can still live in it's atmosphere many miles up. Huge balloons can be covered in solar panels for power. But once again, where to get the building materials. You would either need to capture and mine nearby asteroids, or make aerogels with the Venusian atmosphere. So your basic structural elements like walls, floors, windows, supports, and balloons could be made in situ, anything else like metals would have to be shipped in. That is unless you can develop mining and refining equipment that operates at 450 degrees. unlike Mars; Venus has a generous atmosphere and you won't get zapped by deadly radiation. And i would take a 60C(140F) sky city over the dark and brutally cold Titan. It goes to show how important aiming for interstellar travel is. It would be nice to have more than one planet that has both an atmosphere and a temperature that our technology can easily operate(and you know, support life). EG temperatures warmer than -100C and cooler than 100C. Mars meets that temperature criteria but it lacks any real atmosphere, basically larger version of the moon. Venus sky city is probably the only place other than earth where you can have windows in your Apartment and natural sunlight shining in. Pretty much the rest has you fully enclosed in many feet of radiation shielding. Though with enough power one could look at earth for clues on how to shield from radiation. 1-Forget fossil fuels because you don't have fossil fuels neither oxygen.
2-depending the air speed it would not be a gentle breeze, we don't know for sure the max wind speed in mars, but wing energy depends on V^3 and wind drag force on V^2, so even with little air density plus all that dust in the air, it could really damage stuff if you have winds of 200 kmh. In fact NASA already calculate that wind energy could produce more energy in dust storms than solar in clear days.
3-Earth magnetic field help a bit against radiation, but even if we did not have one, our atmosphere would still block the 98% of the incoming radiation. The magnetic shield helps against solar storms mostly reducing to half or less before the rest is blocked by the atmosphere.
4-For those who think nuclear is an option, not so much, because any radioactive leak on mars would be 200 times more serious than on earth, because in earth you have oceans, atmosphere, rain cycle that helps to dilute and block any radiation leak. Plus it would be way harder to get rid of heat to produce electricity without the chance to use the classic methods we use here.

Or source of oxygen.  This isn't insurmountable but it's just one more critical detail - we have to build some kind of cleaning system into the airlocks.

Adding some stuff to the list:
- Perchlorates! Drinking some untreated Martian water (or cultivating crops in there) will give your thyroid a very bad time...
- Dust Devils! Due to the difference in particle sizes (big particles at the bottom, small at the top) they tend to have a huge electric potential difference from top to bottom. Touching a habitat electrified by a dust devil can easily burn a hole in your suit or fry your life support system with a spark.
- Meteorites! As has been said in the video - no atmosphere, no protection. A small meteorite can rip your garden-dome apart.
